instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to predict the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit?
Output: To predict the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit,the researchers used fluorescence spectrum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to predict the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit?
Output: Six spectral pre-processing techniques were used to pre-process the hyperspectral and fluorescence spectral data for predicting the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit. The best pre-processing methods selected were boxing smoothing (BS) for hyperspectral data and Savitzky-Golay (SG) for fluorescence spectral data.

instruction: What metric was chosen to predict the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen fluorescence spectral is the coefficient of determination (R-squared or R^2). The R-p(2) and R-c(2) values were used to assess the prediction performance of the models based on the hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and fluorescence spectral imaging (FSI) techniques, respectively. 

The R^2 value ranges from 0 to 1, with 1 indicating a perfect fit between the predicted and actual values. In the related study, the R-p(2) and R-c(2) values for the best-performing models were reported as 0.8894 and 0.9429, respectively. 

The RPD (Residual Prediction Deviation) was also used as a metric to evaluate the prediction performance. The RPD value indicates the ratio of the standard deviation of the reference values to the standard deviation of the prediction errors. In this study, the RPD values for the best-performing models were reported as 2.88 and 2.89 for MASS-Boss-ELM and MASS-Boss-PLSR, respectively.

Based on these metrics, the prediction performance of the models in this study was considered to be relatively good.

instruction: What were the results of the regression prediction models (ELM, PLSR, and PSO-LSSVM) in predicting the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit using hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and fluorescence spectral imaging (FSI) techniques?
Output:
The results of the regression prediction models in predicting the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit using hyperspectral imaging (HSI) and fluorescence spectral imaging (FSI) techniques are as follows:

1. Extreme Learning Machines (ELM): The MASS-Boss-ELM model, based on the fluorescence spectral imaging technique, exhibited the best prediction performance for the kiwifruit SSC. It achieved an R-p(2) value of 0.8894, an R-c(2) value of 0.9429, and an RPD value of 2.88.

2. Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR): The MASS-Boss-PLSR model, based on the hyperspectral imaging technique, showed slightly lower prediction performance compared to the ELM model. It achieved an R-p(2) value of 0.8717, an R-c(2) value of 0.8747, and an RPD value of 2.89.

3. Particle Swarm Optimization - Least Square Support Vector Machine (PSO-LSSVM): The results of the PSO-LSSVM model in predicting the SSC in kiwifruit using HSI and FSI techniques were not mentioned in the provided related study.

instruction: How do the prediction performances of the MASS-Boss-ELM model based on fluorescence spectral imaging and the MASS-Boss-PLSR model based on hyperspectral imaging compare in predicting the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit?
Output: The prediction performance of the MASS-Boss-ELM model based on fluorescence spectral imaging is better than the MASS-Boss-PLSR model based on hyperspectral imaging in predicting the soluble solid content (SSC) in kiwifruit. The MASS-Boss-ELM model achieved an R-p(2) value of 0.8894, an R-c(2) value of 0.9429, and an RPD value of 2.88. On the other hand, the MASS-Boss-PLSR model had slightly lower prediction performance with an R-p(2) value of 0.8717, an R-c(2) value of 0.8747, and an RPD value of 2.89. Therefore, the fluorescence spectral imaging technique demonstrated better prediction capabilities for determining the SSC in kiwifruit compared to the hyperspectral imaging technique.
